instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5_REG: What is PP3V3_S5_REG? PP3V3_S5_REG is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state. .
definitions.P3V3SUS_EN: What is P3V3SUS_EN? P3V3SUS_EN is a signal that turns on the PP3V3_SUS power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..

threads.title: [<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A] When does testing require LB in case?
threads.message:
Experts,

I have a purchased <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A, and it seems all my S5 voltages are there. But I'm working on the LB au naturel. I don't expect fan spin because the CPU is not turning on (heating up). The whole board is cool...

It isn't going to S4, so my question is: Is this the point where I need to drop it in the case and connect it?

TIA!

threads.title: [<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A] When does testing require LB in case?
threads.message:
The fan of this board only starts to spin when CPU gets hot.
It spins from first moment if is turned on in SMC bypass mode.

No need to place the board on the shell.
You can ceck for USB activity, being the most used test.
If no S3 voltages present, board doesn't turn on; no reason for further tests.

Use original 60/85W Magsafe 2 charger.
Tell us if you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS at least.

threads.title: [<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A] When does testing require LB in case?
threads.message:
Thanks for the reply & guidance, [USER=682]@2informaticos[/USER].

A. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
on p. 58/82, <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> page:
[B]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG</SIGNAL> = 3.3V [/B]measured at pin 1 (output side) of L7560:
[ATTACH type="full" alt="1655062697996.png"]60659[/ATTACH]

B. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> was a little harder to track down, with some OK, and some no voltage:

-[B]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS_ROM</SIGNAL> = 3.3V [/B](pg.47, <CAPACITOR>C6101</CAPACITOR>, pin 1, which is VCC to <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> & <CHIP>U6101</CHIP>).
-[B]PP3V3_SUS_P3V3SUSFET = 0V [/B](pg.63, <CAPACITOR>C8020</CAPACITOR>, pin 1, which is VIN to "3.3V SUS Switch" <CHIP>U8020</CHIP>)
-[B]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS_FET_R</SIGNAL> = 3.3V [/B](VOUT pin of "3.3V SUS Switch" <CHIP>U8020</CHIP>)
...this implies [B]<SIGNAL>P3V3SUS_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.3V[/B], which it was/is.
On <CHIP>U8130</CHIP> "3.3V SUS Detect" (pg.64 "Power Control"):
-[B]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_PWRCTL</SIGNAL> = 3.3V[/B] (VDD to <CHIP>U8130</CHIP>)
-[B]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS_PWRCTL</SIGNAL> = 3.3V[/B] ("SENSE" on 8130)
Just below <CHIP>U8130</CHIP>, "SUS Enables":
-[B]<SIGNAL>P3V3SUS_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.3V[/B]

I'll keep looking for more <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>* that have 0V, going down the bus list on pg.68

Thanks!

P.S. I really appreciate the help, as too many circuit traces dead end where components on the schematic aren't on the board! ([I]Secret No-Stuff?[/I])

threads.title: [<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A] When does testing require LB in case?
threads.message:
Going down the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> busses on pg.68:

[B]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS_PCH_VCCSUS_GPIO</SIGNAL> = 3.3V[/B]
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS_PCH_VCCSUS_ICC</SIGNAL> = 
[B]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS_PCH_VCC_SPI</SIGNAL> = 3.3V 
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS_PWRCTL</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
PP3V3_SUS_P1V05SUSLDO = 3.3V [/B](<CHIP>U7840</CHIP> "SUS LDO" putting out 1V on PP1V05 _SUS_LDO = OK)
[B]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS_PCH_GPIO</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS_PCH_VCCSUS_RTC</SIGNAL> = 3.3V[/B]

threads.title: [<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A] When does testing require LB in case?
threads.message:
Do you really expect to get different reading on the same power rail???
Impossible, unless you have a broken trace.
Don't waste your time in such manner.

BTW, is better to check DC voltage on the output pin of the coils from buck-converters.

So, if no voltage at L7520, trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for pulse there (at same time).

"-[B]PP3V3_SUS_P3V3SUSFET = 0V [/B](pg.63, <CAPACITOR>C8020</CAPACITOR>, pin 1, which is VIN to "3.3V SUS Switch" <CHIP>U8020</CHIP>)
-[B]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS_FET_R</SIGNAL> = 3.3V [/B](VOUT pin of "3.3V SUS Switch" <CHIP>U8020</CHIP>)"
How can you get output voltage, if no input???
Please, post accurate information.

threads.title: [<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A] When does testing require LB in case?
threads.message:
[USER=682]@2informaticos[/USER],

I'm very sorry, but that/those were what I read, when I read it. I am only reporting voltages I had read. I understand why this is frustrating for you. I apologize on behalf of myself & the LB! :-) 

And now, there is no voltage in or out of <CHIP>U8020</CHIP>.  
VIN, EN and VOUT are [I]all[/I] 0V now.

[May be significant: When the voltages were there, the board was drawing 19mA, not is the first time I have seen it change, and it is now at 14mA.]

I'm now watching the chip (<CHIP>U8020</CHIP>) to see if it is going up & down, but it has been plugged in this whole time (not repowered), and the ammeter is rock steady (at 14mA now instead of 19mA).

Also going upstream of VIN ( via PP3V3_SUS_P3V3SUSFET) to see where it stopped.

Sorry again...

threads.title: [<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A] When does testing require LB in case?
threads.message:
STOP using lab PSU at this moment.
Find original 60/85W Magsafe 2 charger.
Why do you bother with current consumption, if don't get correct expected voltages?

"And now, there is no voltage in or out of <CHIP>U8020</CHIP>."
So you've actually lost <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.
Follow power aliases on page 68, to understand power rails distribution.

What is now exact <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage?
Check <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: [<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A] When does testing require LB in case?
threads.message:
[I]STOP using lab PSU at this moment.[/I]

The PSU is connected to an 85W MagSafe. There are only 2 wires to the power supply from the MagSafe, no?
This is a LR technique, but the bench supply was at 16.5V. 

Begrudgingly, I did as you said, on an 85W 20V PS. And I'll fess up... Fan Spin! Also, the laptop now works.

Thanks 2informaticos!

threads.title: [<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A] When does testing require LB in case?
